August 29, 1999: Fiction
BLACK NOTICE, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $25.95.) Kay Scarpetta's
investigation of a ships's cargo gets her involved in an international conspiracy.
ASSASSINS, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $22.99.) The sixth
volume in a series about true believers who confront the Antichrist.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school for
witchcraft.
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $17.95.) A British boy finds trouble when he returns to a
witchcraft school.
HANNIBAL, by Thomas Harris. (Delacorte, $27.95.) Seven years after his escape,
the fiendish psychiatrist Hannibal Lecter is still at large.
THE EDGE, by Catherine Coulter. (Putnam, $22.95.) F.B.I. agent Mac MacDougal
in pursuit of his sister, whose disappearance is intertwined with baffling crimes.
GRANNY DAN, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A woman learns of her
relative's past in czarist Russia.
MOTHER OF PEARL, by Melinda Haynes. (Hyperion, $23.95.) The lives of a 28-
year-old black man and a 15-year-old white girl converge in Petal, Miss., in the
JUPITER'S BONES, by Faye Kellerman. (Morrow, $25.) L.A. detectives
investigate the death of an astrophysicist who had become the leader of a
pseudoscientific cult.
WHITE OLEANDER, by Janet Fitch. (Little, Brown, $24.) The ordeals of growing
up as experienced by a teen-age girl whose single mother murders a lover.
THE GIRLS' GUIDE TO HUNTING AND FISHING, by Melissa Bank. (Viking,
$23.95.) The progress of a young New York woman through the terrain of sex and
love.
WORST FEARS REALIZED, by Stuart Woods. (HarperCollins, $25.) Stone
Barrington, a cop turned lawyer, seeks a serial killer he knew in the past.
CUBA, by Stephen Coonts. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) With Castro about to die, the
U.S. sends a rear admiral to Cuba to salvage lethal weapons it secretly stored
there.
THE TESTAMENT, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A reclusive billionaire,
a burned-out lawyer and a missionary are brought together by a startling secret.
August 29, 1999
Non-Fiction
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A sportswriter
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
YESTERDAY, I CRIED, by Iyanla Vanzant. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) A counselor
describes how she turned painful experiences into feelings of hope.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The
lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War
II.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead,
$22.95.) What Buddhist doctrines and common sense tell us about dealing with
everyday problems.
SHADOW, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) How the Watergate
scandal affected the Administrations of Richard Nixon's five successors.
BILL AND HILLARY, by Christopher Andersen. (Morrow, $27.50.) A journalist's
account of the marriage of the President and the First Lady.
THE HUNGRY OCEAN, by Linda Greenlaw. (Hyperion, $22.95.) A sea captain's
account of her 30-day swordfishing voyage off the Northeast coast.
ETHICS FOR THE NEW MILLENNIUM, by the Dalai Lama. (Riverhead, $24.95.)
The ethical system Buddhism offers us for the present and future.
THE FIRST WORLD WAR, by John Keegan. (Knopf, $35.) A military historian
recounts the 1914-18 conflict from the viewpoint of the strategists and the men in
the trenches.
CONVERSATIONS WITH GOD: Book 1, by Neale Donald Walsch. (Putnam,
$19.95.) The author addresses questions of good and evil, guilt and sin.
ENCORE PROVENCE, by Peter Mayle. (Knopf, $23.) The author of "A Year in
Provence" recounts further adventures in the south of France.
BELLA TUSCANY, by Frances Mayes. (Broadway, $25.) An American writer
recalls the romantic areas of Italy.
THE LEXUS AND THE OLIVE TREE, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus &
Giroux, $27.50.) A journalist explains the instant electronic global economy.
I AIN'T GOT TIME TO BLEED, by Jesse Ventura. (Villard, $19.95.) Reflections on
politics, pro wrestling and other subjects by the Governor of Minnesota.
SEE JANE WIN, by Sylvia Rimm with Sara Rimm-Kaufman and Ilonna Rimm.
(Crown, $25.) The experiences of 1,000 girls as they became successful women
